question.question-text: Indicate what each type of star is.

explain-list.explain-text: One of the students says if a star is small, it collapses gently and remains collapsed. This is called a white dwarf. From this, it can be determined that a white dwarf is a collapsed small star. You should therefore click in the second column.

One of the students says the first sign of old age is that the star begins to swell and turn red in its outer regions. It's called a red giant. From this, it can be determined that a red giant is a dying star. You should therefore click in the first column.

One of the students says if a star is large, there's a violent explosion…This is called a supernova. From this, it can be determined that a supernova is an exploded large star. You should therefore click in the third column.

question.question-text: What is true about our Sun?

answer-list.answer-text: It is five million years old.
It is one of the largest stars.
It formed from remnants of other stars.

question.explain-text: In the discussion, Doug states that our Sun is an average size, middle-aged star, and Sally states that our Sun was formed from the remains of numerous other stars. This means that our Sun is middle-aged and formed from remnants of other stars. The first and last answers are therefore the best answers to this question.

question.question-text: What causes a star to die?

answer-list.answer-text: Nuclear reactions begin inside of it.
The force of gravity on it diminishes.

question.explain-text: In the discussion, Sally states that when all the hydrogen's used up, the star collapses and dies. This means that a star dies when its hydrogen fuel is gone. The second answer is therefore the best answer to this question.

question.question-text: What will our Sun probably become?
question.explain-text: In the discussion, Doug states that our Sun…will most likely become a red giant in about five billion years; the instructor later states that our Sun is expected to end its life as a white dwarf. This means that our Sun will probably become a red giant and then a white dwarf. The first and third answers are therefore the best answers to this question.
